content:
[adjective] free from dirt, marks, or unwanted substances.
> She likes to keep her room clean and tidy.
> The clean windows allowed plenty of sunlight in.

[verb] to make sounds and movements of the face and body that show amusement.
> The joke was so funny that everyone started to laugh.
> She couldn't stop laughing at the comedian's performance.

[adjective] intelligent or clever.
> He is a smart student who always solves problems quickly.
> The smart design of the phone made it easy to use.

[noun] a very large expanse of sea.
> They enjoyed the view of the ocean from the beach.
> The ship sailed across the vast ocean for weeks.

[adjective] having great physical power or strength.
> The strong wind knocked down several trees.
> She is a strong swimmer and enjoys the sport.

[noun] the property possessed by an object of producing different sensations on the eye.
> The painting was full of vibrant color.
> What is your favorite color?

[noun] the indefinite continued progress of existence and events.
> She spent a lot of time preparing for the exam.
> Time seemed to fly during the holiday.

[noun] a small domesticated carnivorous mammal with soft fur and a retractable claw.
> The cat was purring contentedly in her lap.
> He adopted a stray cat from the shelter.

[verb] to construct something by putting parts or materials together.
> They plan to build a new house near the beach.
> The children decided to build a sandcastle.

[verb] to apply color to a surface using a brush, roller, or other tools.
> She loves to paint landscapes in her free time.
> They decided to paint the walls a bright color.

[adjective] making little or no noise.
> The library was so quiet you could hear a pin drop.
> They enjoyed a quiet evening at home.

[noun] the natural agent that stimulates sight and makes things visible.
> The room was filled with bright light.
> She switched on the light to see clearly.

[verb] to move at a speed faster than walking.
> He decided to run every morning for exercise.
> The children were excited to run in the park.

[adjective] feeling or showing pleasure or contentment.
> She was happy to see her friends again.
> His happy smile brightened everyone's day.

[noun] a set of written, printed, or blank pages fastened together between covers.
> She borrowed a book from the library.
> The book was full of interesting stories.

[noun] a woody perennial plant typically with branches and leaves.
> The old oak tree provided shade on hot days.
> They planted a tree in the backyard.

[verb] to move rhythmically to music.
> They love to dance to their favorite songs.
> She is learning how to dance salsa.

[adjective] giving off lots of light or vivid in color.
> The bright sunlight warmed the garden.
> She wore a bright red dress.

[adjective] having or giving off a moderate degree of heat.
> The warm fire made the room cozy.
> They enjoyed the warm weather at the beach.

[verb] to move through the air with wings.
> Birds fly south for the winter.
> The plane will fly over the mountains.

[adjective] considerate and helpful to others.
> She is a kind person who always helps her neighbors.
> His kind gesture was greatly appreciated.

[adjective] having a smooth and gentle texture.
> The soft blanket kept them warm.
> She loves the soft feel of the kitten's fur.

[noun] a clear liquid that forms the seas, lakes, rivers, and rain.
> They drank cold water after the hike.
> The plant needs water to grow.

[adjective] moving or able to move quickly.
> He drove a fast car on the highway.
> The fast runner won the race.

[noun] a short piece of music with words.
> She sang her favorite song at the concert.
> The bird's song filled the air.

[adjective] not closed or blocked.
> The door was open, letting in a cool breeze.
> They left the window open for fresh air.

[adjective] of considerable size or extent.
> The big tree towered over the house.
> They moved into a big apartment.

[adjective] having a low temperature.
> The cold wind made everyone shiver.
> They enjoyed ice cream on a cold winter day.

[noun] a luminous point in the night sky.
> The stars were shining brightly.
> He used a telescope to observe the stars.

[noun] a deep feeling of affection.
> Her love for music was evident.
> He expressed his love for his family in every action.

[verb] to mark letters or words on a surface.
> She likes to write in her journal every day.
> He decided to write a letter to his friend.

[verb] to push oneself off the ground into the air.
> The cat can jump very high.
> He decided to jump over the puddle.

[adjective] of the color between blue and yellow.
> The green grass covered the hills.
> She wore a green dress to the party.

[verb] to engage in an activity for enjoyment.
> The children went outside to play soccer.
> He likes to play the guitar.

[adjective] having a pleasant sugary taste.
> The cake was very sweet and delicious.
> She loves sweet treats like chocolate.

[adjective] measuring a great distance from end to end.
> The bridge was long and impressive.
> She took a long walk in the evening.

[adjective] moderately cold; not warm.
> The cool breeze was refreshing.
> He wore a jacket to stay warm in the cool evening.

[adjective] solid, firm, and not easily bent.
> The ground was hard after the frost.
> He worked hard to complete the project.

[adjective] free from moisture or liquid.
> The dry desert was vast and silent.
> She hung the clothes to dry in the sun.

[adjective] done with speed.
> He gave a quick answer to the question.
> They needed to make a quick decision.

[adjective] of the color of a clear sky.
> The blue ocean stretched as far as the eye could see.
> She painted the sky a soft blue.

[noun] freedom from disturbance; tranquility.
> The peace of the countryside was soothing.
> They sought peace after a long day of work.

[noun] a set of written or printed pages, usually bound with a protective cover.
> She borrowed a book from the library.
> He enjoys reading a book before bed.

[noun] the natural agent that stimulates sight and makes things visible.
> The morning light streamed through the windows.
> She turned on the light to see better.

[noun] vocal or instrumental sounds (or both) combined to produce harmony and expression.
> He loves listening to classical music.
> They played music at the party.

[noun] the seed-bearing part of a plant, often colorful and fragrant.
> The garden was full of blooming flowers.
> She received a flower as a gift.

[verb] to form one's features into a pleased, kind, or amused expression.
> She couldn't help but smile at the compliment.
> His smile was infectious, spreading joy.

[noun] a series of thoughts, images, or emotions occurring during sleep.
> He had a bizarre dream last night.
> Her dream is to travel the world.

[noun] a woody perennial plant, typically having a single stem with branches.
> The tree provided shade in the hot sun.
> They planted a tree in the backyard.

[noun] an activity one engages in for amusement or fun.
> The board game kept everyone entertained for hours.
> He won the game with a strategic move.

[adjective] feeling or showing pleasure or contentment.
> She felt happy on her birthday.
> The happy couple celebrated their anniversary.

[adjective] lasting for a very short time.
> The beauty of the sunset was ephemeral.
> His success in the competition was ephemeral but memorable.

[adjective] difficult to interpret or understand; mysterious.
> Her smile was enigmatic, revealing nothing.
> The artwork was intentionally enigmatic to provoke thought.

[adjective] fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing.
> She gave an eloquent speech at the conference.
> His eloquent letter moved the audience to tears.

[noun] a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent change.
> The scientist added a catalyst to speed up the reaction.
> Her arrival was the catalyst for change in the company.

[noun] the occurrence of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way.
> Their meeting was pure serendipity.
> The discovery was a stroke of serendipity.

[noun] a complex and confusing network of paths or passages.
> They got lost in the labyrinth of city streets.
> The garden was designed like a labyrinth for visitors to explore.

[adjective] present, appearing, or found everywhere.
> Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern life.
> The branding was ubiquitous throughout the city.

[adjective] representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class.
> She is the quintessential teacher, always patient and kind.
> The book is the quintessential guide to the subject.

[noun] a mode of behavior or way of thought peculiar to an individual.
> His habit of humming was just one idiosyncrasy that made him unique.
> The idiosyncrasies of the writer are evident in the text.

[noun] a pleasant smell that frequently accompanies the first rain after a long period of warm, dry weather.
> The petrichor was refreshing after the summer drought.
> She loved the petrichor that signaled the arrival of rain.

[adjective] too great or extreme to be expressed in words.
> The beauty of the landscape was ineffable.
> She felt an ineffable joy at the news.

[noun] a deep, persistent sadness or sorrow.
> There was a touch of melancholy in the air.
> His music often carries a sense of melancholy.

[adjective] having or showing keen mental discernment and good judgment; wise.
> His sagacious advice was invaluable to us.
> She is known for being a sagacious leader.

[adjective] light, delicate, and translucent, especially of fabric.
> She wore a diaphanous gown.
> The curtains were made of diaphanous material.

[noun] a manuscript or piece of writing material on which the original writing has been effaced to make room for later writing but of which traces remain.
> The ancient palimpsest contained layers of text.
> The city was a palimpsest of cultural history.

[noun] a moment of sudden revelation or insight.
> He had an epiphany about his career path.
> Her painting style changed after an epiphany.

[noun] a harsh, discordant mixture of sounds.
> The cacophony in the busy market was overwhelming.
> The orchestra's cacophony was due to the lack of practice.

[adjective] clear, logical, and convincing.
> She presented a cogent argument for her proposal.
> His speech was cogent and persuasive.

[noun] the realization that each passerby has a life as vivid and complex as your own.
> Walking through the city, he felt a strong sonder.
> Her stories capture the sonder of everyday encounters.

[adjective] denoting a period of time in the past that was idyllically happy and peaceful.
> They reminisced about the halcyon days of their childhood.
> It was a halcyon era in the company's history.

[verb] to think deeply about something.
> She sat by the window to contemplate the future.
> He took time to contemplate the consequences of his decision.

[adjective] lasting for a very short time.
> The beauty of the sunset was ephemeral, disappearing quickly.
> Their joy was ephemeral, fading as soon as the event ended.

[noun] the occurrence of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way.
> It was pure serendipity that they met in the cafÃ©.
> Their discovery of the rare book was a moment of serendipity.

[adjective] not discovered or known about; uncertain.
> The meaning of the ancient text remains obscure.
> His motives were obscure, leaving everyone confused.

[adjective] able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions.
> She showed a resilient spirit in the face of adversity.
> The resilient materials bounced back after the impact.

[adjective] well-meaning and kindly.
> The benevolent king cared deeply for his people.
> She has a benevolent nature, always helping those in need.

[adjective] concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty.
> The aesthetic appeal of the sculpture was undeniable.
> She has a keen aesthetic sense when it comes to design.

[adjective] in a state of rest or inactivity.
> The volcano had been dormant for centuries.
> The seeds remained dormant until the spring rains arrived.

[adjective] fearless, adventurous.
> The intrepid explorer crossed dangerous terrains.
> She was an intrepid journalist, reporting from conflict zones.

[noun] a person or thing that is a perfect example of a particular quality.
> She is the epitome of kindness and generosity.
> His performance was the epitome of excellence.

[adjective] not aware of or concerned about what is happening.
> He was oblivious to the fact that everyone was watching him.
> She walked through the crowd, oblivious to the noise around her.

[verb] to make a problem or situation worse.
> His harsh words only served to exacerbate the conflict.
> The new policy might exacerbate the existing issues.

[verb] to express grief or sorrow.
> She lamented the loss of her childhood home.
> They lamented the passing of an era in the company.

[noun] a person or thing that causes a change or event to happen.
> The discovery of electricity was a catalyst for modern technology.
> Her speech acted as a catalyst for the movement.

[noun] a statement or situation that seems contradictory or impossible but may be true.
> The fact that less is more is a common paradox in design.
> It was a paradox that he could be both strong and gentle.

[adjective] logically connected or consistent.
> His argument was clear and coherent, making a strong case.
> The essay lacked a coherent structure.

[adjective] done with minimal effort or reflection.
> His perfunctory response showed he wasn't really paying attention.
> She gave a perfunctory nod before walking away.

[adjective] generous and forgiving, especially toward a rival or less powerful person.
> The magnanimous leader forgave his opponents' mistakes.
> He was magnanimous in victory, congratulating his competitors.

[adjective] impossible to understand or interpret.
> His inscrutable expression left everyone wondering what he was thinking.
> The ancient manuscript was filled with inscrutable symbols.

[adjective] exceedingly idealistic; unrealistic and impractical.
> His quixotic dream of becoming a superhero made him popular among children.
> The project was abandoned due to its quixotic nature.

[adjective] showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
> She was meticulous in planning her research project.
> The artist's meticulous brushwork created a masterpiece.

[adjective] peculiar or individualistic in nature.
> His idiosyncratic approach to problem-solving baffled his colleagues.
> The artist's idiosyncratic style set her apart from others.

[adjective] wicked or criminal.
> The villain's nefarious plot was eventually foiled by the hero.
> They uncovered a nefarious scheme involving corruption.

[adjective] showing passionate intensity.
> She gave a fervent speech in support of environmental protection.
> His fervent desire to help others led him to volunteer for many causes.

[adjective] having a large appetite or eagerness for something.
> He was a voracious reader, finishing a book every week.
> The team had a voracious appetite for success.

[adjective] lasting for a very short time.
> The beauty of the sunset was ephemeral.
> Their joy was ephemeral, quickly fading away.

[verb] to place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.
> The artist liked to juxtapose bright colors with dark ones.
> The documentary juxtaposes images of war with those of peace.

[adjective] having or showing keen mental discernment and good judgment.
> The sagacious leader made decisions that benefited everyone.
> She was known for her sagacious advice in difficult situations.

[noun] the art of effective or persuasive speaking or writing.
> The politician's rhetoric persuaded many voters.
> He studied rhetoric to improve his public speaking.

[adjective] lasting for a short time; temporary.
> Their stay in the city was transient, just passing through.
> The transient nature of fame is often underestimated.

[adjective] characterized by vulgar or pretentious display to impress others.
> His ostentatious display of wealth alienated many people.
> The party was filled with ostentatious decorations and excess.

[adjective] clever or skillful in using the hands or mind.
> He was adroit at solving complex mathematical problems.
> The adroit craftsman made beautiful, intricate jewelry.

[adjective] having a meaning that is mysterious or obscure.
> The cryptic message left everyone confused.
> His cryptic answers added to the mystery of the situation.

[adjective] having developed certain abilities or proclivities at an earlier age than usual.
> The precocious child could read before she turned three.
> His precocious talent in music impressed everyone.

[noun] a confusing and difficult problem or question.
> Solving the conundrum took all their collective knowledge.
> The team faced a conundrum when they couldn't agree on the strategy.

[noun] a division or contrast between two things that are represented as being entirely different.
> There is a clear dichotomy between the rich and the poor in the city.
> The dichotomy of good and evil is a central theme in many stories.

[adjective] impossible to stop or prevent.
> The inexorable passage of time waits for no one.
> The inexorable rise of technology has changed our daily lives.

[adjective] expressed clearly and easy to understand.
> The professor's lucid explanation helped the students grasp the concept.
> His lucid thoughts were a result of years of experience.

[adjective] clear, logical, and convincing.
> The lawyer presented a cogent argument in court.
> His cogent writing style made the report easy to follow.

[adjective] involving or requiring significant effort; difficult and tiring.
> Climbing the mountain was an arduous task.
> The project demanded arduous attention to detail.

[adjective] present, appearing, or found everywhere.
> Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society.
> The ubiquitous nature of fast food chains is hard to ignore.

[adjective] having deep insight or understanding.
> The book offers profound insights into human nature.
> She experienced a profound sense of relief after hearing the news.

[adjective] having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone.
> He felt ambivalent about moving to a new city.
> Her ambivalent attitude toward the project confused her team.

[noun] polite submission and respect.
> He addressed the elders with great deference.
> Out of deference to her wishes, they postponed the meeting.

[adjective] spreading widely throughout an area or group of people.
> The influence of social media is pervasive in modern life.
> A pervasive sense of uncertainty hung in the air.

[adjective] intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with specialized knowledge.
> The professor's lecture on quantum mechanics was highly esoteric.
> She enjoys studying esoteric subjects in her free time.

[verb] to make something better or less severe.
> Efforts were made to ameliorate the living conditions in the city.
> The therapy helped to ameliorate her anxiety.

[adjective] unchanging over time or unable to be changed.
> The laws of physics are considered immutable.
> His decision was final and immutable.

[adjective] involving a great deal of effort, trouble, or difficulty.
> The contract came with onerous obligations.
> Managing such a large team can be an onerous task.

[noun] a thing belonging to a period other than that in which it exists.
> The use of typewriters in the modern office is an anachronism.
> The movie contained several historical anachronisms.

[adjective] given to sudden changes of mood or behavior.
> Her capricious nature made it hard to predict her reactions.
> The capricious weather ruined their plans for a picnic.

[noun] a feeling of fear or anxiety about something that may happen.
> He approached the exam room with trepidation.
> There was a sense of trepidation before the announcement.

[adjective] unnecessary, especially through being more than enough.
> The report was filled with superfluous details.
> Removing superfluous information made the document clearer.

[noun] the ability to produce a desired or intended result.
> The efficacy of the new drug was tested in trials.
> They questioned the efficacy of the proposed solution.

[adjective] extremely happy, peaceful, or picturesque.
> The countryside offered an idyllic escape from city life.
> They spent an idyllic afternoon by the lake.

[noun] a person or thing that is the direct opposite of someone or something else.
> His actions were the antithesis of his promises.
> The book presents an antithesis between chaos and order.

[noun] a great difference.
> There is a significant disparity in income between the two regions.
> The disparity in resources caused tension among the teams.

[verb] to overwhelm someone with things to be done or to flood.
> The office was inundated with phone calls after the announcement.
> The heavy rains inundated the small village.

[adjective] dealing with things sensibly and realistically in a practical way.
> He took a pragmatic approach to solving the issue.
> Her pragmatic mindset helped the team stay focused.

[adjective] experienced through the feelings or actions of another person.
> She felt a vicarious thrill watching her friend's performance.
> He lived vicariously through the stories of his adventurous siblings.

[noun] a sudden realization or insight.
> She had an epiphany about her career path during the seminar.
> The novel's protagonist experiences an epiphany in the final chapter.

[adjective] persistent, determined, and unwilling to give up.
> His tenacious efforts eventually led to success.
> She was tenacious in pursuing her goals despite challenges.

[noun] conformity to facts; accuracy or truthfulness.
> The journalist's reputation for veracity earned her widespread respect.
> They questioned the veracity of the witness's statement.

[adjective] fond of company; sociable.
> He is a gregarious person who enjoys attending social gatherings.
> The gregarious bird species thrive in large flocks.

[adjective] very attentive to detail and concerned about accuracy.
> She is a fastidious editor who misses nothing.
> The chef was fastidious about the presentation of his dishes.

[adjective] difficult to understand; obscure.
> The abstruse theory required careful study to comprehend.
> His explanations were so abstruse that few could follow.

[verb] to clear someone of blame or suspicion.
> The new evidence helped vindicate the accused.
> She worked hard to vindicate her decision to the board.

[adjective] relating to or consisting of money.
> The contract offered significant pecuniary benefits.
> His motives were purely pecuniary, driven by profit.

[noun] the ability to make good judgments and quick decisions.
> Her business acumen made her a successful entrepreneur.
> He has great acumen in financial matters.

[adjective] having an obstinately uncooperative attitude.
> The recalcitrant student refused to follow the rules.
> They faced challenges dealing with the recalcitrant employee.

[adjective] using very few words.
> His laconic response left them wanting more details.
> The teacher appreciated his laconic but accurate explanation.

[adjective] unreasonably high (especially in cost or price).
> The hotel charged an exorbitant fee for basic services.
> She refused to pay the exorbitant rent.

[adjective] severe or strict in manner, attitude, or appearance.
> The monk lived an austere lifestyle.
> The room's austere design emphasized simplicity.

[adjective] deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.
> Her music collection is eclectic, featuring a variety of genres.
> The restaurant offers an eclectic menu from around the world.

[noun] a natural tendency to behave in a certain way.
> He has a proclivity for solving complex problems.
> Her proclivity for art became apparent at an early age.

[verb] to infer or estimate by extending known information.
> Scientists extrapolate future trends based on current data.
> It's risky to extrapolate conclusions from limited evidence.

[adjective] having a particular habit, activity, or interest that is long-established.
> He is an inveterate traveler who has visited over 50 countries.
> Her inveterate curiosity drives her to learn continuously.

[adjective] reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little.
> The taciturn student rarely participated in class discussions.
> Despite his taciturn demeanor, he was very observant.
